channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Should Common Plastics Be Labeled Toxic?
item.description: A group of global scientists, writing in Nature this week, argues that some plastics should be classified as hazardous and handled accordingly.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:credit: Ben Fogletto/The Press of Atlantic City, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Less than half of all plastics produced last year ended up on landfills or in recycling programs.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: How Much Do You Trust Journalists?
item.description: A new poll demonstrates, once again, widespread lack of trust in journalists. Has journalism really lost its way, or does the public always get the press it deserves?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: A London news stand displaying British newspapers on Friday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Singapore's Immigration Debate, Sign of Asia's Slipping Middle Class?
item.description: Immigration is controversial everywhere. But does a recent protest in Singapore point to a deeper problem: a weakening middle class in Asia, with similar sentiments in Hong Kong, too? What do you think?
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Blasts Across Baghdad Kill at Least 21 People
item.description: A wave of attacks targeting Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad on Sunday killed at least 15 people and wounded more than 50, a security source confirmed.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Explosion in Crowded Market Kills Dozens in Pakistan
item.description: At least 84 people died in a neighborhood dominated by Hazaras, a Shiite ethnic minority that has suffered numerous attacks at the hands of Sunni militants in recent years.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A bomb killed scores of people on Saturday at a market in Quetta, Pakistan, in a Shiite minority neighborhood.

item.title: Dismissed as Doomsayers, Advocates for Meteor Detection Feel Vindicated
item.description: The meteor that rattled Siberia on Friday brought new life to efforts to deploy adequate asteroid detection tools.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: Dr. Edward Lu, a former NASA astronaut and Google executive, has warned about space threats.

item.title: In Korea, Changes in Society and Family Dynamics Drive Rise in Elderly Suicides
item.description: The number of suicides among people 65 and older has nearly quadrupled in recent years, ranking the country’s rate of such deaths among the highest in the developed world.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Lee Geum-sook, a volunteer, right, trying to comfort Yoon Jeom-do, an 89-year-old woman who lives alone in Seoul.

item.title: A Ticket, a Lie and a British Official’s Downfall
item.description: A traffic violation 10 years ago has led to the political downfall of the British cabinet minister Chris Huhne and put the intimate details of his former marriage on display.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The case pits Vicky Pryce, center, against her former husband, Chris Huhne.

item.title: Supreme Leader Says Iran Not Seeking Nuclear Arms
item.description: But Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said nothing could stop his country from building nuclear weapons, should it choose to do so.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: White House Continues Work on Its Own Immigration Bill
item.description: Aides are working on a bill that would offer illegal immigrants a pathway to citizenship — a measure intended as a backup in case a bipartisan effort by Congress stalls.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Karzai to Forbid His Forces to Request Foreign Airstrikes
item.description: President Hamid Karzai said he would issue a decree barring the Afghan military from asking international troops to carry out airstrikes under “any circumstances.”
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai will decree a ban in the wake of a strike that killed 10 civilians and wounded this boy in Kunar Province.

item.title: The Education Revolution: In China, Families Bet It All on a Child in College
item.description: Millions of Chinese sacrifice heavily for their children’s education, but as college graduates saturate a slowing job market, the security they seek is increasingly elusive.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Wu Caoying studied English under her father’s watchful eye in 2006. She is now a sophomore in college.

item.title: Bomb Strikes Mogadishu at Beachside Restaurant
item.description: Witnesses and the police reported that a Somali soldier had been killed and up to three other people wounded.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Damage from a remote-controlled bomb at Lido Beach in Mogadishu on Saturday, where Somalis flock on the weekends.

item.title: Vast Throng in Bangladesh Protests Killing of Activist
item.description: An organizer’s death reignited demonstrations demanding the death penalty for those found guilty of war crimes in the nation’s 1971 independence fight.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Mourners in Bangladesh on Saturday carried the coffin containing the body of Rajib Haider, an organizer who was killed.

item.title: Some Chinese Are Souring on Being North Korea’s Best Friend
item.description: The sense of fraternity appears to be souring as ordinary people express anxiety about possible fallout from North Korea’s nuclear test last Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A billboard showing Mao Zedong, right, and North Korea’s founding father, Kim Il-sung, near the China-North Korea border.

item.title: Syrian Kidnappings Raise Fear of Expanded Conflict
item.description: The recent kidnappings of more than 140 have demonstrated not only the high level of insecurity in the area, but also the determination of residents to defuse tensions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Russians Seek Clues and Count Blessings After Meteor Blast
item.description: As the government pursued the scientific mysteries of Friday’s exploding meteor, residents reacted to their survival with giddy relief and humor.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Ben Solomon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police and reporters examined a 20-foot hole in the ice of Chebarkul Lake, one of several sites in Siberia where fragments from a meteor were believed to have struck the earth on Friday.

item.title: Explosion in Crowded Market Kills Dozens in Pakistan
item.description: The bombing in Quetta occurred in an area dominated by a Shiite ethnic minority that has suffered many attacks at the hands of Sunni militants.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistani paramedics on Saturday examined the bodies of bombing victims at a hospital in the western city of Quetta.

item.title: Militants Infiltrate Towns in Freed Areas of Mali
item.description: Militant forces that once controlled major towns appear to have taken refuge in smaller villages nearby.
item.dc:creator: By PETER TINTI and ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Travelers from Niger approached a soldier on Tuesday to be searched outside the city of Gao, which was attacked days earlier.

item.title: Pope Electors Are Sizing Up a Field of Peers
item.description: The cardinals who will file into the Sistine Chapel next month to elect a new leader of the Roman Catholic church have been quietly evaluating potential successors for years.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: A portrait of Cardinal Luis Antonio Tagle is hung in Manila next to one of the man some people think he might succeed.

item.title: Keiko Fukuda, a Trailblazer in Judo, Dies at 99
item.description: Ms. Fukuda learned judo from its founder and went on to become the sport’s highest-ranked woman.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Keiko Fukuda with students at the San Francisco dojo where she taught for more than 40 years.

item.title: Pressure for Peace With Taliban Is Renewed
item.description: Eight countries’ diplomats are refocusing on talks between Afghanistan and the Taliban before NATO troops leave, but sharply different visions for peace have hindered the effort.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, Pakistan, the United States and the Taliban all have different visions of how to achieve peace after 2014.

item.title: Group of 20 Pledges to Let Markets Set Currency Values
item.description: At the end of a conference in Moscow, the group promised: “We will refrain from competitive devaluation. We will not target our exchange rates for competitive purposes.”
item.dc:creator: By DAVID HERSZENHORN

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: Indian Troops Kill Pakistani Soldier in Kashmir Border Clash
item.description: Indian soldiers returned fire to fight an intruder, an army statement said.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
